I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  International  Public  Sector  Accounting  Standards  Board  (IPSAS  Board)  is  a 
standards-setting body designated by and operating under the auspices of the International 
Federation of Accountants (IFAC).1 One of the main functions of the IPSAS Board is to develop 
financial  reporting  standards  for  public  sector  entities.  From  1997  to  2008,  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  provided  three  phases  of  regional  technical  assistance  (TA)  to 
support the IPSAS Board's standards-setting program.2  
 
2.  During the third phase, the IPSAS Board set standards for employee benefits, changes 
in foreign exchange rates, impairment of cash-generating assets, and disclosure by recipients of 
external assistance.  
 
3.  Additionally, the IPSAS Board issued five new standards3 and revised 12 more. Several 
studies on accounting issues were undertaken.4 The IPSAS Board also initiated a conceptual 
framework for the preparation and presentation of financial statements in the public sector. 
 
4.  Standards set by the IPSAS Board provide the foundation for achieving the long-term 
objectives of (i) moving toward cash-based or full-fledged accrual accounting for both developed 
and developing countries, and (ii) improving the quality and reliability of accounting and financial 
reporting for the public sector. Following successful completion5 of the first three phases of the 
TA, the proposed fourth phase is to support the IPSAS Board's 2009–2011 work program 
(Appendix 2) which focuses on producing a series of accounting guidelines and standards to 
improve and strengthen accountability and transparency in public sector financial reporting. The 
IPSAS Board’s work program is consistent with the ADB Strategy 20206 and its development 
agenda on good governance, anticorruption, and an enhanced government fiscal management 
system. 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  At the completion of the third phase of the TA, the IPSAS Board identified and prioritized 
several projects related to the convergence of International Public Sector Accounting Standards 
with the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). These included the following:  
                                                 
1  IFAC was established in 1973 and was formally approved by the International Congress of Accountants in 1977. 
IFAC  is  the  global  organization  for  accountancy  profession  dedicated  to  serving  the  public  interests  by 
strengthening the profession and contributing to the development of strong international economies. The IFAC 
Board established the public sector committee in 1986 to issue pronouncements on accounting, auditing, and 
reporting in the public sector on IFAC’s behalf. Effective 10 November 2004, IPSAS Board replaced the public 
sector committee. 
2  ADB. 1997. Technical Assistance for Government Accounting Standards. Manila (TA 5748-REG, for $245,000); 
ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance for Government Accounting Standards (Second Phase). Manila (TA 6052-REG, 
for $245,000); ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Public Sector Accounting Standards (Third Phase). Manila (TA 
6336-REG, for $245,000). 
3 IPSAS 22: Disclosure of Information about the General Government Sector, IPSAS 23: Revenue from Non-
Exchange  Transactions—Taxes  and  Transfers,  IPSAS  24:  Presentation  of  Budget  Information  in  Financial 
Statements, IPSAS 25: Employee Benefits, and IPSAS 26: Impairment of Cash Generating Assets.  
4 Including Government Financial Reporting: Accounting Issues and Practices, Perspectives on Cost Accounting for 
Governments, Governance in the Public Sector: A Governing Body’s Perspective, and Transition to Accrual Basis 
of Accounting: Guidance for Governments and Government Entities. 
5  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance Completion Report for RETA 6052: Government Accounting Standards (Second 
Phase). Manila; ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance Completion Report for TA 5748: Government Accounting 
Standards, Manila. The technical completion report for TA 6336-REG is being finalized. 
6 ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila.

2   
 
(i)  Financial instruments—convergence with International Accounting Standards7 (IAS) 32, 
IAS 39 and IFRS 7. Exposure drafts8 were developed in 2008 and approved in 2009. 
The IPSAS Board anticipates approving these standards in late 2009. 
(ii)  Equity  combinations—convergence  with  IFRS  3:  Business  Combinations  as  well  as 
separate related public sector specific projects.9 The exposure draft was approved in 
2009, while the public-sector-specific part is targeted to be completed in 2011. 
(iii)  Intangible assets—convergence with IAS 38: Intangible Assets. 
(iv)  Agriculture—convergence with IAS 41: Agriculture. 
 
6.  The IPSAS Board continues to make significant progress on projects that are specific to 
the public sector. 
(i)  Conceptual  framework  for  public  sector  financial  reporting.  A  very  significant 
milestone  for  the  project  was  the  issuance  of  the  phase  1  consultation  paper 
(Conceptual  Framework  for  General  Purpose  Financial  Reporting  by  Public  Sector 
Entities:  The  Objectives  and  the  Scope  of  Financial  Reporting,  The  Qualitative 
Characteristics of Information included in General Purpose Financial Reporting, The 
Reporting Entity).   
(ii)  Long-term fiscal sustainability. A project brief paper was issued in 2008 and a task 
force  was  formed  to  develop  a  framework  for  governments  to  develop  fiscal 
sustainability reports. 
(iii)  Service concession arrangements and public–private partnerships. A consultation 
paper was issued in 2008 (Accounting and Financial Reporting for Service Concession 
Arrangements), and, after additional analysis and consultations, an exposure draft was 
developed. The estimated project completion is 2010–2011.  
(iv)  Review  of  the  cash-basis  standards.  The  review  is  ongoing  and  scheduled  for 
completion in 2010–2011. 
(v)  Social  benefits.  An  exposure  draft  (ED  34;  Social  Benefits:  Disclosure  of  Cash 
Transfers to Individuals and Households) was issued in March 2008. During further 
consultations in October 2008 it was agreed to defer development of the standards until 
the conceptual framework project is completed. 
(vi)  Financial instruments. At its October 2008 meeting, the IPSAS Board considered the 
financial  instruments  project  in  the  context  of  the  global  financial  crisis  and  three 
exposure drafts were approved in March 2009. The exposure drafts for non-contractual 
items, such as taxes, will be developed during 2009–2011. 
 
7.  These projects will be further developed during the fourth phase of the TA, which will 
support the IPSAS Board standard's development program in 2009–2011. During consultations 
with representatives of the member countries of the IPSAS Board, developing member country 
(DMC) governments, accounting bodies, the accounting profession, and multilateral financial 
institutions, the IPSAS Board recognized the complexity of establishing accounting standards 
for the public sector and strengthened the work program for the next phase to address the 
concerns and issues that had been raised. 
 
                                                 
7 IAS 32: Financial Instruments Presentation, IAS 39: Financial Instruments: Recognition and Measurement, and 
IFRS 7: Financial Instruments: Disclosures. 
8 "Exposure drafts" are issued by IPSAS Board and posted on the IFAC website for comment.   
9  The IPSAS Board is also working on a project that addresses entity combinations where the combining entities are 
under common control and the combination is a non-exchange transaction.

3 
8.  While the IPSAS Board has developed and produced a series of accounting guidelines, 
standards, and studies under the previous phases of the TA, many important tasks remain to be 
completed. Given the global financial crisis, the development of a new set of standards for 
recognition and  measurement  of  financial  instruments,  and  the  updating  of  disclosure  and 
presentation requirements, is important if the public sector is to have a robust set of accrual 
based accounting standards.  
 
9.  The IFAC Group of Twenty (G20) accounting summit10 called attention to the urgency of 
the standards convergence program for the public sector, which has proceeded more slowly 
than convergence in the private sector. Faster progress is critical to enhance sound regulations, 
strengthen transparency and the financial reporting infrastructure, and improve the financial 
management capabilities of countries. Because the IPSAS Board has lacked resources in the 
past, a significant gap in accounting standards has opened up between IPSAS and IFRS. 
Currently, the IPSAS Board is trying hard to close this gap.   
 
10.  At  the  G20  IFAC  summit,  it  was  acknowledged  that  IPSAS  can  only  be  properly 
implemented if public sector bodies have professionally qualified accountants with appropriate 
technical  skills.  To  achieve  financial  stability  and  develop  the  capacity  of  the  accounting 
profession  in  developing  and  emerging  economies,  a  number  of  initiatives,  including  a 
framework for building sustainable capacity for the accounting profession, are being undertaken 
through the member body development group at IFAC in coordination with the IPSAS Board 
and other standards-setting boards.  
 
11.  The IPSAS Board, under IFAC's lead,6 has undertaken a number of initiatives, including 
updating  the  Study  on  Transition  to  the  Accrual  Basis  of  Accounting  –  Guidance  for 
Governments and Government Entities11 to reflect the 2009 IPSAS Board handbook. A second 
stage of updating will be undertaken in 2010. Additionally, the IPSAS Board held round table 
meetings to review the problems in implementing the cash-basis IPSAS and an exposure draft 
was posted. The IPSAS Board work program for 2009–2011 includes continuing to work on 
capacity development initiatives and ADB, through its involvement in phase four of the TA, will 
deepen its cooperation with the IPSAS Board in this area and will develop a professional 
training scheme to strengthen the capacity of accounting professionals. 
 
12  Improving accounting and financial reporting in the public sector is a long-term process. 
The IFAC has asked ADB and its other development partners to continue financing its ongoing 
development program. A number of developing partners and bilateral donors have agreed to 
support the IPSAS Board's work program for 2009–2011 and to contribute to its budget. The 
World Bank has agreed to support the IPSAS program and has increased its contribution from 
$130,000 in 2007 to $250,000 a year from 2009.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  By supporting the IPSAS Board's work program for 2009–2011, this TA will enhance 
accountability and transparency in government financial reporting and accounting systems by  
                                                 
10 The IFAC G20 accounting summit was held in London on 23–24July 2009 to achieve consensus by the profession 
on a series of recommendations to be made to G20 leaders on issues related to the financial crisis.  
11 IFAC. 2004. Study 14: Transition to the Accrual Basis of Accounting – Guidance for Governments and Government 
Entities.NewYork.

4   
 
(i) facilitating accounting policy reform, (ii) strengthening accountability and transparency in 
government  financial  reporting,  and  (iii)  enhancing  the  capacity  development  initiatives  to 
strengthen the accounting profession. 
 
14.  The expected impact of the TA will be improved public financial management. The 
expected outcome will be enhanced accountability and transparency in government financial 
reporting and accounting systems. To date, 28 Asian and Pacific countries12 and 10 nonregional 
ADB member countries13 either have adopted or are in the process of adopting IPSASs. In 
2009, Indonesia and the Kyrgyz Republic, among others, were in the process of adopting 
IPSAS or converging their national standards with IPSAS. Further progress in the adoption of 
IPSAS during 2009–2011 will help to strengthen financial governance in ADB's DMCs.  
 
15.  The outcome will be achieved through the following outputs: (i) completion of agreed 
public sector specific projects, (ii) approval of an IPSAS and IFRS convergence program; and  
(iii) implementation of a communication strategy (Appendix 1). 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  The key activities of the fourth phase of the TA are to (i) complete the development of 
public sector specific IPSAS (cash- and accrual-based); (ii) finalize IPSAS for the exposure 
drafts under review; (iii) continue an extensive program  so IPSAS  converge with IFRS or 
national standards; (iv) implement communication strategies to promote IPSAS; (v) continue to 
develop  public  sector  specific  projects,  including  a  conceptual  framework,  long-term 
sustainability, and service concession arrangements and public–private partnerships projects; 
and (vi) work with IFAC on a capacity development program to strengthen the accounting 
profession.  
 
17.  With this continuing TA support, ADB will maintain its “observer” status, along with other 
funding agencies, and attend the IPSAS Board’s conferences and meetings to ensure that the 
best interests of ADB DMCs are taken into consideration in the different outputs of the IPSAS 
Board's work program. 
 
18.  Copies of all IPSAS exposure drafts and studies can be downloaded free of charge at 
the IFAC website (http://ifac.org). In addition, the information on the availability of translated 
versions of the IFAC's Handbook of International Public Sector Accounting Pronouncements,14 
will be disseminated to ADB DMCs through ADB resident missions.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The  total  cost  for  the  fourth  phase  work  program  for  2009–2011  is  estimated  at 
$5,197,000 equivalent ($1,732,333 per annum). ADB will provide $300,000 equivalent on a 
grant basis from ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–IV). Other multilateral aid 
                                                 
12 The following countries in the Asia and Pacific region have adopted or are in the process of adopting IPSAS: 
Armenia, Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, Australia, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Cambodia, People's Republic of China, Timor-
Leste, Fiji Islands, India, Indonesia, Japan, Kazakhstan, Lao People's Democratic Republic, Maldives, Malaysia, 
Mongolia,  Nepal,  New  Zealand,  Pakistan,  Philippines,  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Singapore,  Sri  Lanka,  Uzbekistan, 
Vanuatu, and Viet Nam. 
13 The following nonregional member countries of ADB have adopted or are in the process of adopting or converging 
to IPSAS: Austria, Canada, France, Germany, the Netherland, Norway, Spain, Switzerland, United Kingdom, and 
United States. 
14 IFAC. 2009. Handbook of International Public Sector Accounting Pronouncements. New York.

5 
agencies, governments, and organizations will provide parallel financing of $2,270,000 on a 
grant basis as follows: (i) the World Bank, $750,000; (ii) Government of Canada, $450,000; (iii) 
Canadian  Institute  of  Chartered  Accountants,  $450,000;  (iv)  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China, $420,000 (in-kind); (v) United Nations, $100,000; and (vi) Government of 
New  Zealand,  $100,000.  IFAC  will  provide  the  remaining  $2,627,000.  Details  of  the  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The IFAC will be the executing agency for the fourth phase of the TA. As ADB is only 
contributing 5.8% to the IPSA Board's 2009-2011 work program budget, together with the World 
Bank  and  other  organizations,  it  would  be  practical  and  efficient  for  IFAC  to  use  its  own 
organizational and administrative procedures, similarly to the arrangements in the previous 
three phases of the TA. The IFAC will implement the TA through the IPSAS Board. ADB funds 
will be used to cover part of the technical inputs of 6.5 full-time staff of the IPSAS Board, 
international  travel,  meetings,  conferences,  seminars,  workshops,  and  miscellaneous 
administrative and support costs. No consulting services or equipment will be procured and 
financed from ADB funds. 
 
21.  TA implementation will commence in December 2009 and is expected to be completed 
in October 2012. The ADB funds will be released in three installments each amounting to 
$100,000. The first installment will be released upon receipt by ADB of the TA letter agreement 
countersigned by IFAC. Two subsequent installments will be released based on the submission 
of (i) a financial statement of account showing the use of grant funds from various funding 
agencies, (ii) a copy of the audited financial statements of IFAC with supplementary information 
on the IPSAS Board projects, and (iii) a brief annual progress report on the project activities 
supported by the TA, as will be specified in the TA letter agreement to be executed between 
ADB and IFAC. The IFAC will maintain separate records with respect to ADB's portion of the 
financing and provide to ADB not later than 6 months after the end of each fiscal year in which 
ADB funds are utilized, a copy of the audited financial statements of IFAC with supplementary 
information on the IPSAS Board projects. 
 
22.  As an observer of the IPSAS Board, ADB will monitor and oversee TA activities. ADB 
will also provide direct input to the work of the IPSAS Board by reviewing its exposure drafts, 
consultation papers and ensuring that ADB member countries comments are addressed before 
IFAC issues any guidelines and directives.15 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis for 
Public Sector Accounting Standards (Fourth Phase), and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.
                                                 
15 The Financial Management Practice Community Group within ADB will be utilized to seek consolidated institutional 
comments on the exposure drafts, consultation papers, draft IPSAS, and other related papers. The updates on the 
IFAC and IPSAS Board activities will also be circulated through this group.
